en.value: Saying how someone looks and communicating in a clothes shop - Irregular verbs in the past simple
Listen to the dialogue. What are they talking about?
When we are shopping for clothes or talking about style, we use lots of words and expressions to give our opinion. We’re now going to learn some useful things we can say when talking about clothes.
They go well with my new trainers.
Red doesn't suit her. She looks better in blue.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Those trousers look really nice on you.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
You can use different adjectives after the verb “to look” to give an opinion on someone’s clothes.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Select the words in the correct order.
What does Anita think about her new dress?
It goes well with her shoes.
We can also say that something is "a good fit", if something is of the right size or shape. "To fit" and "to be a good fit" are similar in meaning. Have a look at the two examples below.
Match the beginning and the end of the sentences.
If something "suits" someone, it means it is right for that person. It makes the person look good or looks good on that person.
Theo: Yeah! It looks great on you.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Have another quick look at the words we've learned.
to match, to look good next to something
to be the right size and shape
to be right for someone / something
Ripped jeans are very fashionable at the moment.
Now let's learn a few words that will help you to talk about style and fashion. For example, clothes can be...
acceptable or not too high in price
If something is "fashionable", it means it is on trend.
We wear "casual clothes" to formal events.
We wear "casual clothes" (casual clothes) to informal occasions.
"Smart casual" is a dress code that we often use for social occasions and some workplaces. It means neat and stylish, but not too formal!
The party dress code is smart casual.
What is this jacket made of?
We use "to be made of" when we talk about the fabric of our clothes. Some common fabrics are leather, cotton, wool and polyester.
Marie: What's your blazer made of, Louise?
I like it, but it is a bit too expensive.
That's a reasonable price for those shoes.
Select the two words that have opposite meaning.
To recap, let's listen to the dialogue again and practise some more!
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Logan and Ava are chatting at work.
Logan, why are you looking so [k]smart[/k] today?
I’m going out with a friend tonight.
Very nice! I like your blazer. What is it [k]made of[/k]?
No idea. I just bought it because it [k]goes well with[/k] my jeans.
That type of blazer is very [k]fashionable[/k], too.
Yeah. Do you think it’s a good fit? I wasn’t sure.
What might we say if someone looks stylish?
Select the verb that we use to say that something makes someone look nice.
fit fashionable [h]suit[/h] expensive be made of
Match each word with its opposite.
Cathie thinks the price for the jacket is fair. Type the missing word.
That's a [k]reasonable[/k] price for this jacket.
Short skirts are very f[k]a[/k]s[k]h[/k]i[k]o[/k]na[k]b[/k]le at the moment.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Ted is praising Anna's new dress. Type the missing words.
It [k]looks great|looks ok|looks nice|looks good|smart|fashionable|expensive[/k] on you.
How do we call a stylish but not too formal dress code? Type the missing word.
Clarissa has finally found the right pair.
This dress [k]goes well[/k] with those shoes.
Chat to a member of the busuu community about your style. What clothes look nice on you? Which colours suit you best?
... look(s) good on me. / ... do(es)n't suit me. / I look better in ...
Romy goes shopping for a new pair of shoes.
Excuse me, could I [k]try these shoes on[/k], please?
There you go. What do you think?
They fit, but I'm not sure if they go with my dress. I'm going to a wedding, so they might be too casual. I need to think about it, if that's ok?
Of course! You can also try them on at home and [k]return[/k] or [k]exchange[/k] them if you don't like them.
That sounds great! I might come back later and [k]collect[/k] them. Could you put them aside for me?
Going shopping is much easier when you know how to ask for a different size or a refund. Let's have a look at some words that might help you with that! Here are some of the expressions we'll learn.
Can I try these on, please?
I need to return these items.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Can I try these on, please?
Do you need a different size?
I'd like to try on this dress please.
This means that she wants to see if the dress fits her.
In terms of sentence order, we can put the item that we want to try on after or in the middle of the phrasal verb "to try on". Have a look below to see an example.
I'll think about it, if that's ok.
We can say "I'll think about it" or "I might come back later" if we're not entirely sure yet if we want to buy something.
Shop assistant: So, were the trousers a good fit? Do you like them?
John: I'm not sure, I'll think about it, if that's ok.
Shop assistant: Of course! Should I put them aside for you?
John: That would be great, I might come back later.
I'll think about it, if that's ok.
This means he wants to buy what he's tried on.
This means that he's not sure yet and needs more time to decide.
I'm here to collect an order.
I need to return these items, please.
I'd like to collect an order please.
The speaker wants to return something.
She wants to pick something up.
He [h]collected[/h] my order from the shop.
I [h]returned[/h] the shoes the next day.
Can I exchange this skirt, please?
You can exchange the shoes, if you like.
This means you could bring the shoes back to the shop and swap them for another item.
Select the correct translation of the word you can hear.
We can also use the verb "to refund" to describe the process of giving a refund to someone. Have a look below to see both the noun and the verb in context.
I'll refund the purchase price for you.
I'll give you a refund for this.
Select the verb that describes the process of getting money back.
They [h]refunded[/h] the full purchase price! The refund should be in my account next week.
Excuse me, could I [k]try[/k] these shoes [k]on[/k] please?
Select what we might say when we’re unsure whether we want to buy something.
I need to think about it.
Match each word with its definition.
Can I try those shoes on?
to take time for a decision
Complete the sentence to say that you might visit the store again.
I'm not sure yet, I might [k]come[/k] [k]back[/k].
Complete the sentence to express that you want to bring something back to the shop.
to swap one item for another
I need to [k]exchange[/k] these jeans, they're too small.
Excuse me, could I [k]try on[/k] these shoes please.
Complete the sentence to talk about how big the shoes need to be.
Listen to the audio. Select the statement that is true.
He's not sure about the clothes yet.
He wants to pay right away.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
She [k]collected[/k] the order from the store.
I would like to [k]return[/k] this jumper please.
Select the correct definition of the word you hear.
to bring an item back to the shop
to wait before buying an item
I need to e[k]x[/k][k]c[/k][k]h[/k][k]a[/k][k]n[/k][k]g[/k]e these jeans, they're too small.
Complete the sentence to say that you'd like your money back.
I'd like to get a [k]refund[/k] please.
Grammar: More irregular verbs in the past simple
Claire is spending a few days in London with her boyfriend. She sends her friend a message to tell her how it's going. You'll notice she uses the past simple, with some irregular verbs.

Hey Lauren, London is a great city! On Friday night we decided to go to a new restaurant. I thought (to think) it was quite expensive and we spent (to spend) a lot of money! Yesterday I went shopping and found (to find) a nice dress for your birthday party. David didn't go with me, he took (to take) a taxi and came (to come) to the hotel. Hope everything is good with you. Speak to you soon!
I spent a lot of money yesterday.
We found a new restaurant in town.
I found a dress that I liked.
This sentence talks about the past.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
They [k]spent[/k] all their money on presents.

Irregular verbs don't have a standard form in English, so we have to learn them individually. Don't worry though, we'll practice with different exercises so by the end of this unit you'll feel like a pro!
She spent too much money on lunch.
He found a nice place to live.
My sister bought lots of clothes from a new shop in town.
I thought the film was very good.
My daughter came home very late last night.
She wore a lovely dress to the party.
Select the three irregular verbs in the past simple.
My friend recommended this book, so I [h]bought[/h] it.
My sister [h]came[/h] to visit us and she stayed for dinner.
He [h]wore[/h] the new suit to work.
Sophia [k]came[/k] home very late last night.
To recap, let's take a look at the irregular verbs we've just seen!
The verb in bold is the past simple form of "to wear".
She wore a lovely dress to the party.
Complete the sentence: They ... a taxi to the restaurant last night.
Listen to the dialogue. Select the two irregular past simple verbs that you hear.
Match each verb with its past simple form.
I [k]bought[/k] a nice pair of shoes and [k]wore[/k] them yesterday to the party.
Select the verb whose past simple form you hear.
I [k]f[/k][k]o[/k][k]u[/k][k]n[/k][k]d[/k] your keys in my bag.
Match each verb with its past simple form.
Re-write the verb in the past simple
I [k]found[/k] this pen on the table, is it yours?
She [k]came[/k] to the party with me.
They [k]bought[/k] a new car but I don’t like it.
